defs.docs: # SPECS Parallel ECS

attributes.value: / This library provides an ECS variant designed for parallel execution
/ and convenient usage. It is highly flexible when it comes to actual
/ component data and the way it is stored and accessed.
/ * depending on chosen features either 0 virtual function calls or one per
/ One could basically split this library up into two parts:
/ The data part and the execution part.
/ `World` is where component storages, resources and entities are stored.
/ See the docs of [`World`] for more.
/ [`Component`]s can be easily implemented like this:
/ Or alternatively, if you enable the `specs-derive` feature, you can use a
/ You can choose different storages according to your needs.
/ These storages can be [`join`]ed together, for example joining a `Velocity`
/ and a `Position` storage means you'll only get entities which have both of
/ them. Thanks to rayon, this is even possible in parallel! See [`ParJoin`]
/ Here we have [`System`] and [`Dispatcher`] as our core types. Both types
/ are provided by a library called `shred`.
/ The `Dispatcher` can be seen as an optional part here;
/ it allows dispatching the systems in parallel, given a list
/ of systems and their dependencies on other systems.
/ If you don't like it, you can also execute the systems yourself
/ `System`s are traits with a `run()` method and an associated
/ This is a basic example of using Specs:
/ // A component contains data which is
/     // These are the resources required for execution.
/     // You can also define a struct and `#[derive(SystemData)]`,
/     fn run(&mut self, (mut pos, vel): Self::SystemData) {
/         // so we only access those entities which have
/         // This joins the component storages for Position
/         // and Velocity together; it's also possible to do this
/     // An entity may or may not contain some component.
/     // This entity does not have `Vel`, so it won't be dispatched.
/     // Since we only have one, we don't depend on anything.
/     // This dispatches all the systems in parallel (but blocking).
/ You can also easily create new entities on the fly:
/ See the repository's examples directory for more examples.

/ must be callable from multiple threads, simultaneously, without mutating

attributes.value: / The purpose of the `Join` trait is to provide a way
/ to access multiple storages at the same time with
/ Joining component storages means that you'll only get values where
/ for a given entity every storage has an associated component.
/ # struct Pos; impl Component for Pos { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/ # struct Vel; impl Component for Vel { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/     // There are no entities yet, so no pair will be returned.
/     // Although there is an entity, it only has `Pos`.
/     // Now there is one entity that has both a `Vel` and a `Pos`.
/     // If we want to get the entity the components are associated to,
/     // note: `EntitiesRes` is the fetched resource; we get back
/     // `Read<EntitiesRes>` can also be referred to by `Entities` which
/     // is a shorthand type definition to the former type.
/ `Join` can also be used to iterate over a single

Returns a `Join`-able structure that yields all indices, returning

attributes.value: / Returns a `Join`-able structure that yields all indices, returning
/ `None` for all missing elements and `Some(T)` for found elements.
/ WARNING: Do not have a join of only `MaybeJoin`s. Otherwise the join
/ will iterate over every single index of the bitset. If you want a
/ join with all `MaybeJoin`s, add an `EntitiesRes` to the join as well
/ to bound the join to all entities that are alive.
/ # struct Pos { x: i32, y: i32 } impl Component for Pos { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/ # struct Vel { x: i32, y: i32 } impl Component for Vel { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/     fn run(&mut self, (mut positions, velocities): Self::SystemData) {
/         for (mut position, maybe_velocity) in (&mut positions, velocities.maybe()).join() {

/ If the `Mask` does not correctly report the status of the `Value`
/ then illegal memory access can occur.

defs.name: is_unconstrained
defs.docs:
If this `Join` typically returns all indices in the mask, then iterating
 over only it or combined with other joins that are also dangerous
 will cause the `JoinIter`/`ParJoin` to go through all indices which
 is usually not what is wanted and will kill performance.

defs.name: MaybeJoin

A `Join`-able structure that yields all indices, returning `None` for all
 missing elements and `Some(T)` for found elements.

attributes.value: / A `Join`-able structure that yields all indices, returning `None` for all
/ missing elements and `Some(T)` for found elements.
/ WARNING: Do not have a join of only `MaybeJoin`s. Otherwise the join will
/ iterate over every single index of the bitset. If you want a join with
/ all `MaybeJoin`s, add an `EntitiesRes` to the join as well to bound the
/ join to all entities that are alive.

defs.name: ReadStorage
defs.docs: A storage with read access.

attributes.value: / This is just a type alias for a fetched component storage.
/ The main functionality it provides is listed in the following,
/ however make sure to also check out the documentation for the
/ **It is strictly disallowed to get both a `ReadStorage` and a `WriteStorage`
/ Because Specs uses interior mutability for its resources, we can't check
/ this at compile time. If you try to do this, you will get a panic.
/ It is explicitly allowed to get multiple `ReadStorage`s for the same
/ This joins the position and the velocity storage, which means it only
/ iterates over the components of entities that have both a position
/ If you have an entity (for example because you stored it before
/ or because you're joining over `Entities`), you can get a single
/ # struct Pos; impl Component for Pos { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/ # struct Vel; impl Component for Vel { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/ # let mut world = World::new(); world.register::<Pos>(); world.register::<Vel>();
/ get it inside a system by simply adding it to the tuple:
/             println!("Entitiy with id {} has a position of {:?}", ent.id(), pos);
/ These operations can't mutate anything; if you want to do
/ insertions or modify components, you need to use `WriteStorage`.
/ Note that you can also use `LazyUpdate` , which does insertions on
/ `World::maintain`. This allows more concurrency and is designed
/ to be used for entity initialization.

defs.name: WriteStorage
defs.docs: A storage with read and write access.

attributes.value: / A storage with read and write access.
/ Additionally to what `ReadStorage` can do a storage with mutable access
/ **It is strictly disallowed to fetch both a `ReadStorage` and a
/ Because Specs uses interior mutability for its resources, we can't check
/ this at compile time. If you try to do this, you will get a panic.
/ It is also disallowed to fetch multiple `WriteStorage`s for the same
/ This works just like `Storage::get`, but returns a mutable reference:
/ # struct Pos(f32); impl Component for Pos { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/ You can insert components using `Storage::insert` and remove them
/ # struct Pos(f32); impl Component for Pos { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/     println!("Overwrote {:?} with a new position", p);
/ There's also an Entry-API similar to the one provided by

Inserts a component using a lazily called function that is only called
 when inserting the component. Ensures this entry has a value and if not,
 inserts one using the result of the passed closure. Returns a reference
 to the value afterwards.

/         // out the ones you want to modify.
/         // Instead you will want to restrict the amount of components iterated over, either through

defs.name: RestrictedStorage
defs.docs:
Similar to a `MaskedStorage` and a `Storage` combined, but restricts usage
 to only getting and modifying the components. That means it's not possible
 to modify the inner bitset so the iteration cannot be invalidated. In other
 words, no insertion or removal is allowed.

defs.name: DistinctStorage
defs.docs: This is a marker trait which requires you to uphold the following guarantee:

attributes.value: / This is a marker trait which requires you to uphold the following guarantee:
/ > Multiple threads may call `get_mut()` with distinct indices without
/ This is for example valid for `Vec`:
/ We may modify both element 1 and 2 at the same time; indexing the vector
/ mutably does not modify anything else than the respective elements.
/ As a counter example, we may have some kind of cached storage; it caches
/ elements when they're retrieved, so pushes a new element to some
/ cache-vector. This storage is not allowed to implement `DistinctStorage`.
/ Implementing this trait marks the storage safe for concurrent mutation (of

defs.name: Component
defs.docs:
Abstract component type.
 Doesn't have to be Copy or even Clone.

attributes.value: / Doesn't have to be Copy or even Clone.
/ Components are stored in separated collections for maximum
/ cache efficiency. The `Storage` associated type allows
/ to specify which collection should be used.
/ Depending on how many entities have this component and how
/ often it is accessed, you will want different storages.
/ The most common ones are `VecStorage` (use if almost every entity has that
/ component), `DenseVecStorage` (if you expect many entities to have the
/     // In an ECS, the camera would not itself have a position;
/     // you would just attach a `Position` component to the same

defs.name: Entities
defs.docs:
A wrapper for a read `Entities` resource.
 Note that this is just `Read<Entities>`, so
 you can easily use it in your system:

attributes.value: / A wrapper for a read `Entities` resource.
/ Note that this is just `Read<Entities>`, so
/ you can easily use it in your system:
/ Please note that you should call `World::maintain`
/ after creating / deleting entities with this resource.
/ When `.join`ing on `Entities`, you will need to do it like this:
/ # struct Pos; impl Component for Pos { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/ # let entities = world.entities(); let positions = world.write_storage::<Pos>();

defs.name: LazyUpdate
defs.docs:
Lazy updates can be used for world updates
 that need to borrow a lot of resources
 and as such should better be done at the end.
 They work lazily in the sense that they are
 dispatched when calling `world.maintain()`.

attributes.value: / Lazy updates can be used for world updates
/ that need to borrow a lot of resources
/ and as such should better be done at the end.
/ They work lazily in the sense that they are
/ Lazy updates are dispatched in the order that they
/ are requested. Multiple updates sent from one system
/ may be overridden by updates sent from other systems.
/ Please note that the provided methods take `&self`
/ so there's no need to get `LazyUpdate` mutably.
/ This resource is added to the world by default.

defs.name: WorldExt
defs.docs:
This trait provides some extension methods to make working with shred's
 [World] easier.

attributes.value: / This trait provides some extension methods to make working with shred's
/ Many methods take `&self` which works because everything
/ is stored with **interior mutability**. In case you violate
/ the borrowing rules of Rust (multiple reads xor one write),
/ While components exist per [Entity], resources are like globals in the
/ `World`. Components are stored in component storages ([MaskedStorage]),
/ Everything that is `Any + Send + Sync` can be a resource.
/ Both of them should only be fetched immutably, which is why
/ the latter one has a type def for convenience: `Entities` which
/ is just `Fetch<EntitiesRes>`. Both resources are special and need
/ to execute code at the end of the frame, which is done in
/ # struct Pos { x: f32, y: f32, } impl Component for Pos { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/ # struct Vel { x: f32, y: f32, } impl Component for Vel { type Storage = VecStorage<Self>; }
/     // `Storage::get` allows to get a component from it:
/     // This time, we write to the `Pos` storage:
/     // You can also insert components after creating the entity:

defs.name: is_alive
defs.docs:
Checks if an entity is alive.
 Please note that atomically created or deleted entities
 (the ones created / deleted with the `Entities` struct)
 are not handled by this method. Therefore, you
 should have called `maintain()` before using this
 method.

defs.name: maintain
defs.docs:
Merges in the appendix, recording all the dynamically created
 and deleted entities into the persistent generations vector.
 Also removes all the abandoned components.

defs.name: Builder
defs.docs:
A common trait for `EntityBuilder` and `LazyBuilder`, allowing either to be
 used. Entity is definitely alive, but the components may or may not exist
 before a call to `World::maintain`.
